div.head: General Remarks
div.p: Here is the complete documentation for 84000 TEI Documents. In the body there is a list of all the specifications for element, model classes, attribute classes, macros, and datatypes. The back matter contains first a set of guidelines for our own markup editors showing the process for the markup stage of our texts, which is then followed by some other appendices with further topeics and instructions for markup editors. All of these sections are accessible through links in the table of contents.

NOTE FOR UPDATING THE SCHEMA: This ODD contains some content models that are written directly with RELAX NG in order to shape and restrict the form for published 84000 texts. If these need to be updated in the ODD these content models, which outline the whole of the text are primarily to be found in the elementSpecs for the front, body, and back elements. Some RELAX NG content models are also defined in the elementSpecs the child elements of the teiHeader but these should be simpler and easy to navigate.

remarks.p: body (text body) contains the whole body of a single unitary text, excluding any front or back matter. So in an 84000 TEI encoded document, the body contains the whole translated text. It does not material written by the translator or editors, but just the original text in translation. It is part of the text, coming after front and before back. The body section opens approximately the same way in every document. The front closing tag precedes the body opening tag. That is followed by the div tag with the type attribute containing the "translation" value. This is followed by the head elements, with type values first of "translation" and then "titleMain", and then "titleHon" as shown below. After this comes the chapter or section div's, and so on. Even if there is no chapter division in the body of the translated text, there is minimally one section or chapter div, containing then the whole of the translation, and closing before the "colophon". Structurally the colophon section is equivalent to a chapter, and colophon is a value of a type attribute of a div element. The colophon div closes and then comes the closing div tag of the translation, and then the closing body tag.

Because of the particularities of electronic publishing, P5 Guidelines says that "the term edition may be used for a particular state of a machine-readable text at which substantive changes are made and fixed. The words revision and update, by contrast, are used for minor changes to a file which do not amount to a new edition. No simple rule can specify how ‘substantive’ changes have to be before they are regarded as producing a new edition, rather than a simple update. The general principle proposed here is that the production of a new edition entails a significant change in the intellectual content of the file, rather than its encoding or appearance. " For 84000 texts, the element should include a version number or name and can include the date element.

According to the TEI P5 Guidelines, editionStmt (edition statement) is the second component of the fileDesc element and groups information relating to one edition of a text. It is an optional element, but recommended. It follows directly after the /titleStmt, and proceeds the publicationStmt. There are 5 potential child elements that it can contain, but for 84000 texts, the only child element is the edition tag, and that element contains in turn the date element, the grandchild of the editionStmt element.

remarks.p: The major source of information for those seeking to create a catalogue entry or bibliographic citation for an electronic file. As such, it provides a title and statements of responsibility together with details of the publication or distribution of the file, of any series to which it belongs, and detailed bibliographic notes for matters not addressed elsewhere in the header. It also contains a full bibliographic description for the source or sources from which the electronic text was derived.

remarks.p: 84000 uses this element to tag foreign words throughout documents with exception for the titles of texts, which should be tagged with the title element. All instances of the foreign element must contain the xml:lang with its value following the ISO 639-1 codes with the exception of romanized transliteration of Sanskrit, Tibetan, and Chinese, which are given the value "Sa-Ltn", "Bo-Ltn", and "Zh-Ltn" respectively. Most instances of the foreign element should include the type attribute detailed above, although there are a few exceptions when foreign text will not fall into the "term", "quote", or "mantra" category and this attribute is not needed, for instance, the case of Tibetan Wylie transliteration given in parenthesis after the phonetic rendering of a Tibetan name. However, in general romanized foreign names should not be tagged with the foreign element. This tag should only be used for foreign text that are to be italicized according to 84000's style guidelines, as our parser will italicize all instances of foreign text in the web display. There is one exception to this, in that text in the Tibetan and Chinese script should be tagged with the foreign element, but will not be italicized in the parser.

The front (front matter) contains any prefatory matter. It is the first section of the text structure, so it comes after the teiHeader, which is outside of the text itself, and before the body, which is the second part of the text proper. The front matter of an encoded text should not be confused with the TEI header. The TEI Header, serves as a kind of front matter for the computer file itself, not the text it encodes. The front contains the written material that does not form part of the translated text, including the summary, acknowledgement and introduction (in that order). remarks.p: In the glossary found in the back material of each 84000 text, the gloss element wraps each glossary term with its variations in Tibetan and Sanskrit along with a definition. The gloss element is requires the xml:id attribute, and the type attribute declaring whether it is a "term", "person", "place", or "text". The first term element (which has no attributes and presents the English translation of the term) will create a link to the glossary in the reading room for each instance of that term as it appears as a string in the text. However, in some cases it may be inappropriate to link certain strings of text that match this term and so optionally the mode attribute may be added with the values of "marked" or "match". A gloss element with the mode "match" will match with all instances of that string in the text unless they are marked with <term type="ignore">. A term in the glossary with the mode "marked" will only link to terms with the term element. of the term, that are marked also by term tags the type attribute with the value of "alternate".

There also may be occasions were the translator has used alternate translations for the same term, or different variations for the spelling of a string that correspond to the same glossary entry. In this case an additional term element should be added with the value "alternative". This will cause the parser to link these alternate string instances of the text in 84000's reading room.

div.head: Summary
div.p: In Teaching the Relative and Ultimate Truths, the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī is summoned by Buddha Śākyamuni from a faraway buddha realm to teach in a way that demolishes all dualistic experience. As Mañjuśrī begins to teach, the main message of the sūtra unfolds as an explanation of the two truths. The general theme of Mañjuśrī’s discourse is centered on the particular circumstances in Ratnaketu’s buddha realm, but the message is equally applicable to the experiences of beings here in this world.

item.label: Chapter 1: The Introduction
item.p: The Buddha Śākyamuni is on Vulture Peak Mountain outside Rājagṛha with a great gathering of bhikṣus and bodhisattvas. Candraprabha asks him for instruction. The Buddha states that evenness of mind is the one quality that will bring enlightenment and the attainment of the samādhi called the revealed equality of the nature of all phenomena, which is described as having an array of qualities that covers all the various aspects of the path. On hearing this, a multitude of beings attain various stages of realization; the earth shakes, and a radiance illuminates the universe.

remarks.p: Unlike section or chapter tags, label tags do not result in a real structural section of the text. A reader need to click a button to go to the next chapter. The label tag is a less obtrusive heading tag, labeling parts of texts, and not designating major sections. labels will appears in bold text in a slight larger type than the rest of the text, but the same color and same font.

Currently we are not using level 3 div elements in the front, front matter or body, body. And so the label element may be used to separate a new subsection in substitution for making a new third level division, for instance in a chapter by chapter summary found in the introduction of some texts.

q.p: “Blessed One, there is an extensive collection of discourses on the Dharma that bears the name Lalitavistara (The Play in Full). This teaching illuminates the basic virtues of the bodhisattvas, showing how the Bodhisattva descended from the sublime palace in the Heaven of Joy, intentionally entered the womb, and sojourned in the womb. remarks.p: The following description from the University of Michigan is available as part of a PDF at http://www.lib.umich.edu/files/departments/dpp/20101113_06.pdf "The TEI header (teiHeader) is the ‘virtual title page’ of a TEI document. It contains meta data (information about the TEI document). teiHeader is the first, mandatory child element of the root TEI element; therefore, it appears at the top (‘at the head’) of every TEI document. The header meta data provides: 1. bibliographic record of the electronic text as well as the source from which the electronic text is derived 2. documentation of the encoding and editorial principles used in tagging the electronic text 3. terms for indexing, searching, and retrieval 4. a record of changes made to the electronic document. The header contains many specialised elements not found anywhere in the ‘body’ of a TEI document (that is, everything after the close of teiHeader). These elements allow for highly structured descriptions of the document. Many parts of the header allow free-form prose descriptions as an alternative to the highly structured descriptions. Few header elements are required, so a header can be quite minimal."

remarks.p: Primarily the term element is used to list glossary terms in the back matter of a text. For each individual gloss element, which constitutes a single glossary entry, a list of several term elements are used. The first term shows the English translation of the term or the string used in for that term in the text. This entry will not have any attribute, and in the web display, the parser will link every instance of that term to the glossary entry in the back. The following term elements show the Wylie, Tibetan, and Sanskrit for that term, all indicated by the xml:lang attribute with the appropriate value. After that a definition is given in its own term element with the type="definition" attribute. Finally if there are any alternate translations used for the term within the text that should be linked to this gloss, they are listed last with type="alternative". This will also link instances of this alternative string throughout the text to this glossary entry. All of this can be seen in the following example. For further notes about the glossary see Appendix C.
In the case of the 84000 translations, the text element is opened right below the teiHeader element. It includes within it the translated work, as well as the front and back matter.

div.head: Enter the Word DOC into the Template
div.p: (If this hasn't already been done by the copy editors. However, if you receive a text form the copy editors, it is important to check their work and make sure the text has been placed properly into the template.)

list.item: In general you can follow the instructions written into the template.

Paste the text into all the appropriate sections using the "Heading 1,2" styles to outline the text. Make sure that the style “Heading 3” or higher isn’t used anywhere in the document, as that information will be lost in the conversion process. Any headings for third level subsections (or more) written by the translator should be set to the “Normal” style in the style set.
Apply all the various styles to the italics in the text
Apply the "verse style" to verses and format the verses (change the display settings to show paragraph marks and line breaks so you can see more clearly if they are formatted correctly).

div.head: Transform the New DOC To TEI-XML

list.item: At some point we will develop a script to do this, but until then
Use oxgarage at: http://www.tei-c.org/oxgarage/ using this platform change “Microsoft Word .docx” to “TEI P5 XML Document”

Download and open the XML in oXygen and use the .xslt style sheet to transform the XML document. to do this:
A. Click on “Configure Transformation Scenarios” (it should be a wrench with a red arrow on the oXygen ribbon.
B. Select “New” > “XML transformation with XSLT”
C. For the XSL URL: click on the drop down menu next to the folder and select “Browse Data Source Explorer”
D. Select 84000 Collaborations > apps > 84000-reading-room-collab > data > xslt > oxGto84000.xsl
E. For the “Transformer:” select “Saxon-PE 9.6.0.7” from the drop down menu.
F. Click on the “Output” tab and check the box that says “Open in Editor”
G. Click okay, and then select “apply associated” (the transformation scenario you just made should be ticked under “projects”)

This should create a file that is closer to what we want. However, the script is definitely not perfect and many sections, particularly the teiHeader will need some reworking. For this, it is best to refer to a previously published text to see if the formating matches. If any further "hi" tags or other tags need to be changed through out the text, the refactoring tool is very helpful for this (Tools > XML Refactoring...)
Save the XML to the 84000 collaboration database and begin editing the XML so that it may be displayed on the web page.

In general, while going through the text, it is important to refer back to the .docx you received from the copy editor. If the document has an unusually formatted outline, some portions of text may be lost in the XSLT conversion. A good way to check this is open the original .docx and look at the outline of the text (On PC go to “View” and check the box that says “Show Navigation Pane”; on Mac go to “View” > “Sidebar” > “Document Map Pane”; this might be different for other versions of Word). For example if there are any third level headers or extra divisions in the summary or acknowledgements these sections may disappear. It is particularly good to check the front material, and the bibliography for anything unusual.
Make sure all the elements are nested properly (It should give you errors if they are not)
Look for all "hi" and remover or change them appropriately
Look for any weird tags that shouldn't be there like "type="endnote text"" or any other relics from the oxgarage/script conversion
Look for any mistakes: typos, mislabled tags, etc...
Using a previously edited TEI document as a model, make sure everything is formatted in the same way.
Add the appropriate "type" attributes to all the div elements (use a previously edited TEI doc as a model)

If the introduction and main traslation only has one section you will probably see this heading at the beginning of their second level div elemnet:
Main Section
this is actually a placeholder from the template and it should be removed as the heading from the previous div element will provide the heading "Introduction" or "The Translation".

Milestones should be generated automatically by the script before every p element and lg element; however, we don't use milestones as uniformly as this, and some of the milestones will need to be taken out ( for instructions on how to do this see appendix D).

Note that all "xml:id" attributes, "tid" attributes in the p elements, and "index" attributes in the note elements will be added automatically when you upload the XML, so you don't need to worry about adding these.
notes cannot be in left headers or titles, move these notes into an appropriate place within the text itself.

Apply the Schema which should be in “84000 Collaboration > apps > 84000-reading-room-collab > data > schema > 1.0 > tei.rng” . You will see any schema errors as red bars on the right column in the oXygen window. Note that the schema isn’t perfect yet so some errors might not really be errors and some errors might be missing, however the schema is the best way to see if the XML is going to work correctly in the parser. If later on you have trouble saving to the database or you can save to the database but the web page will not display the text, then checking for schema errors in oXygen is the best way to start. If it says that there is an error in a place where you don’t think there is really an error but you need to text the XML for web display, you can comment out that section with comment tags:
<!-- -->(or highlight and press Ctrl-Shift “,”) then you can will be able to temporarily block all the seeming schema errors to help identify the problem.
Transform the xlsx file with the “convert-glossary-from-tei.py” python script.

Note, you might not be familiar with python script, python can be a bit finicky so go ahead and give it a try, but Celso and Mike can do these transformations later if you can’t get python running on your computer or if the script isn’t working properly. I couldn’t get the right version of python to run on my PC, but I did get it to run on my Mac. If you are able to get it on PC please add those instructions and update this checklist:
1. Download and install the latest version of Python 3. I believe the script we use won’t work in Python 2. I use the mac version 3.6.3

2. Now that you have python installed, create a folder on your desk top and name it “convert” This will be the folder inside of which all your conversions will occur. You will need to have Celso or Mike email the python script to you. The script is a file labeled “convert-glossary-from-tei.py”. Put this file in the “convert” folder you just created.

3. First we need to convert the .xlsx file into an .xml file using oxgarage. We can do this the same way we converted the .docx file earlier: convert from spreadsheet > .xlsx to “TEI P5 XML Document” (Note, I’ve tried this with .xls spreadsheets and it hasn’t worked, if this happens try saving the .xls as a .xlsx with Excel and trying again. Also sometimes the Oxgarage will stop working and then suddenly a week lately it will work again. Sorry, I know this is frustrating, contact Celso or Mike if you are running into this hurdle.)
4. Now take the .xml file converted from oxgarage and place it in the “convert” folder on your desk top. Change the name of this .xml file to “input.xml”
5. Now we can run the script. The easiest way on the mac is to open an application called IDLE, which comes with the python download. It should be in the main Python folder after you install it.

6. Open IDLE and go to “file > open” and open the “convert-glossary-from-tei.py” file. This should open up a new window which will show the script as a bunch of code. From this new window go to “Run > Run Module”. This will run the script and create the converted file in the folder you made with the name “output.xml”

7. The script is finicky and often times it won’t work. Sometimes is will break halfway through and the file will be incomplete. If you get an error message open up the “input.xml” file with oxygen or any text editor. The most likely problem is that there is an empty row in the spreadsheet that is causing the script to break. For instance you will see in the text rows labeled as <row n="1"> followed by a bunch of <cells> and then <row n=”2”> and so forth. Most of the <cells> had the data from the .xslx file, but see if you can find where the <row> is suddenly followed by a bunch of empty unused cells. Delete those empty cells (just for that row) and try running the script again. If it still isn’t working you can try sending it to me (Celso) and I can try to find out why it isn’t working.

Continuing with step 4. Transforming and Editing the Glossary: If you get the script to work, or have someone else convert it for you, you can then paste it into the XML text you are working on. Use another already published TEI file as a model.
Edit the glossary. Note that when you save the file to the database it will add various attributes like the “xml:id”, and “priority”, so you don’t need to worry about adding these.

Check for errors and make sure the tags are nested properly. Use previously edited 84000 TEI XMLs as a model. You might want to save it first, so it automatically adds all the attributes and so forth.

div.p: Next, optional soft-hyphens should be entered into this text for any long Sanskrit chains. The guidelines for doing this are shown in Appendix E: Guidelines for entering Soft Hyphens to Sanskrit

div.head: Add Links For References (Both In-Text and External)
div.label: In-Text References:
div.p: When ever we have internal citations like this we should use the ptr element to make a link in the text. For example, if you go to the Vimalakirti Sutra and look at note 5. It says:

q.p: "See 2.3. It is especially appropriate, in the light of the early tantric tradition, for Vimalakīrti, as a layman, to be an adept."

div.p: The "2.3." links to that milestone. If you look at this note in the XML it says:
div.egXML: See . It is especially in the light of the early tantric tradition, for Vimalakīrti, as layman, to be an adept.
div.p: The "ptr" element creates the link and you will have to find the "xml:id" value for that milestone and enter it in as the value for the "target" attribute. If you look at our XML for 10,000 right now in the database, notice that all the xml:id's were put in automatically when I uploaded it yesterday. You don't put the actual milestone number, because the parser will automatically put the milestone number in the link. That way if the milestones get shifted later on, we won't have to update it again.
Notice there is a comment "<!--2.3-->" after the tag in the Vimalakirti note. This is a comment just to keep track of where the pointer links to according to the milestone numbers in the web display.

Make these links for all page references (these should be highlighted by the copy editors, but if they aren't try to clarify what milestone they are intended to link to, and link to and mark up the pointers appropriately.

References to notes, e.g., "see note 5" should be linked to the "xml:id" of the appropriate note as well. Often the notes will be changed causing the whole numbering to shift slightly, so you will likely need to search and clarify which is the correct note to link to (usually it will only be shifted a few numbers up or down so if it says "see note 5", then it will likely be int the 3-7 range for instance). If you are not sure where the references is referring to, or there is some ambiguity, then make a note about this for the leading editors.

The ptr element can also create links to the bibliography. To link to specific bibl entries use the xml:id of those entries, or to link to the general bibliography section use the target value of "#bibliography". For example:
div.label: External Links:
div.p: Occasionally there will be citations to external 84000 texts, that have been highlighted by the copy editors to link. This can be done so, not by using the ptr element, which is only used for in-text citations; but it is done with the ref element with the web address as the value of the target attribute. For example see this reference in the King of Samadhis Sutra (Toh. 127):

egXML.note: Unidentified Indian musical instrument. It appears in two lists of instruments in the Lalita­vistara­sūtra (see The Play in Full 15.39 and 15.67) with a stringed instrument preceding and following it, but some recent Tibetan-English dictionaries have “cymbals.”

div.p: This will link the milestone references "15.39" to that corresponding passage in The Play in Full (Toh. 95).
Links to other web addresses can be done in the same way.

div.head: Upload the XML and See How it Looks on the Web Page

list.item: Go through the text again looking at the web display making sure everything looks okay.

It is helpful at this point to put the web page in “editor mode” all this does is underline all the linked glossary terms for you. Otherwise in the regular display it underlines them but then they will disappear after a few seconds, which will be frustrating when your are checking the links. To put it in editor mode just add the following text to the end of the URL web address: ?view-mode=editor

At this point you should check to see that the glossary is linking to the right terms. Particularly in the summary and introduction there may be many instances of a word linking to the glossary when it shouldn’t, for example in the phrase “in terms of…” the word “term” might link to the glossary for the technical meaning of “term” or in the phrase “with respect to…” the word “respect” might link to “respect” as in devotion (these are just some examples). To fix these instances you should use the add the mode to the gloss element in the glossary. If you change it to mode="match" (this is the default mode, by the way) you will be able to block strings in the text you don't want to link by marking them with the tag term type="ignore" If you change it to mode="marked", it will only link with strings in the text that are tagged within the term element (you will need to mark each instance of the term individually in this case). In rare cases you might need to use both modes. For example in Toh. 127 there are two gloss entries for the term "conceptualization", and there are some instances of this word that should link to the first gloss, some that link to the second, and some that link to neither. In this case the first gloss it set to mode="marked" and the second has the default mode="match", then terms that should link to the first are marked with the term element, the ones that should link to the second are left untagged, and the terms that should link to neither are marked term type="ignore".

div.head: Final Details
div.p: A few final things to look out for while going through your final run of the text:

list.item: extra blank spaces.
double check links and make sure they go to the right places.

make sure links aren't missing, sometimes if the little "#" is missing or misplaced in the "target" attribute in the ptrs then the reference want appear at all and you will see text like "(see above, .)" without anything coming after them.
do a search for comment tags we may have left in by accident in the XML, you can do a quick search for "<!--"

double check for any “hi” tags. They may be italics that were missed when the text was entered into the template, so you may need to change them to title or foreign, be sure to check back with the original .docx if this looks like the case.
any formatting or anything else that just looks wrong or awkward.
if there are any grammar or editing errors that you think may have been missed in the copy-edit phase, be sure to make notes of them to send to the leading editor in an email at the end.

As you work on the text, make a running list of any problems or issues that you cannot fix yourself and make this into a final list of questions/issues to send to the leading editor. There are often a lot of things that come up, so is good to make a final list so the leading editor can look through them more systematically in one email.

div.head: Italics
div.p: In a given text, words or phrases may be italicized for different reasons. The need to express both presentation information (that text is italicized) as well as the semantic information about why it is italicized must be addressed. That is why instead of simply using the hi element, for example, the voices below form the markup menu for text that needs to be italicized:

list.item: emph or distinct term, words, or phrases singled out (any language)
foreign xml:lang="" foreign words or phrases in non-Asian languages (French, Latin…)
foreign type="term" xml:lang="" a foreign term in parentheses following its translation (Sanskrit, Tibetan)
foreign type="term" xml:lang="" a relatively rare foreign term (Sanskrit, Tibetan)
title xml:lang="" title of a work (any language)
foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn" Wylie transliteration (Tibetan)
foreign type="quote" xml:lang="" quotations from texts in notes (Sanskrit, Tibetan)
foreign type="mantra" xml:lang="" mantras or seed-syllables (Sanskrit)

div.p: Note that Tibetan script and Chinese characters should be given the xml:lang value of "bo" and "zh" respectively, while Tibetan, Chinese, and Sanskrit romanized transliteration should have the values of "Bo-Ltn", "Zh-Ltn", "Sa-Ltn" respectively. For all other langues use the the ISO 639-1 codes to find the appropriate xml:lang value.

For the most part, these tags should be added during the copy editing phase in the 84000 Template.doc. In this phase they will be added as styles in MS Word, but will be transformed in to the appropriate tag by our scripts. However, as we can't add a style for every language in the template, the markup editor will need look up and edit the tags for any uncommon languages, which will be marked through the script as xml:lang="Input Language". Also there may be errors or italicized texts that was missed, which the markup editor should keep an eye out for.

div.head: Divisions
div.p: elements are used within a text to mark different sections of the text. This is of particular importance as the head tag can only follow directly after a "div" marker or another head tag. The main sections of the text are marked as follows:

list.item: div type="summary" Wraps the Summary section
div type="acknowledgement" Wraps the Acknowledgement section
div type="introduction Wraps the Introduction
div type="translation" Wraps the entire translation
div type="notes" Wraps the notes section; this section is needed for displaying abbreviations
div type="listBibl" Contains a group of bibl elements, wraps the bibliography
div type="appendix" To wrap the appendix of a text, eg a Sanskrit Appendix
div type="colophon Wraps the colophon

div.p: Within those major document units or divisions, there are other sub units, especially chapters or their equivalent. Both chapter and section refer to the same hierarchical level in the xml. Chapters are the type value used in the body of the text when they have been specified as chapters by the translator. Section is used for equivalent level sectioning that have not been called chapters. Examples for the latter are sectioned bibliography, where the who;e of the bibliography has multiple sections organized by source type. in that case div type="section" is used instead of div type="chapter". from a structural point of view, however, they are the same.

list.item: div type="chapter" Wraps a chapter, which is part of the translation.
div type="section" Wraps a section of the TEI document

div.p: For example:
and

div.head: Outlines
div.p: Sometimes the introduction of a text will provide an outline, particualrly for a longer or more complicated text. Within the TEI XML these outlines should be contructed using the list and itemelements. For a complex outline with many levels of subsections, the outline itself should be contained in a list, and each section should be contained in an item within that list. Then, for each sub section, a new list element should be nested within those items which in turn contains its own subsections with item elements, and so forth for as many subsections that are necessary. To keep track of the levels, the list element should have the rend="numbered" attribute, and each item should have an "n" attribute designating that section of the outline with integer numbers and periods as in: n="1", n="1.1", n="1.2", n="1.2.1" etc. For example see the following outline from "The Baskets Display" (Toh 116):

egXML.p: This outline is intended as a guide to the complicated narrative levels of the sūtra.

item.p: I. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni is in the Jetavana Monastery when lights appear, transforming the monastery’s appearance. Bodhisattva Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin questions Buddha Śākyamuni about this, and the Buddha states that the cause of the lights is Avalokiteśvara visiting Avīci hell and then the city of the pretas.

1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara appears in the Avīci hell and liberates beings. As a result, Yama’s creatures go to Yama and describe Avalokiteśvara’s arrival. Yama goes to Avalokiteśvara and praises him.
II. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni responds to a question from Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin about whether Avalokiteśvara has left the hell.
1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara leaves the hells, visits the city of the pretas, and liberates them from their suffering. This very sūtra sounds in their realm.

div.p: This will allow the outline to be properly displayed in the 84000 reading room. The "n" attribute is only needed for complex outlines with two or more levels. If the outline is a simple list of chapter descriptions then this "n" attribute is not necessary, though the list and item elements should still be used.

div.head: Cross References and Links
div.label: Milestones:
div.p:
Cross references in the text that refer to milestones will be added using a ptr element with the "target" attribute. The value of the target should be a hashmark ("#") followed by the xml:id value ot the milestone that is to be lined. For example:
See .
The milestone number as it appears on the webpage may be listed as a comment aftwards, but the parser will automatically show the milestone number in the web display. This way even if the milestones shift around it will still display and link to the correct milestone on the web page.
div.label: Notes and Bibliography:
div.p: Notes and Bibliography entries work in the exact same way, for the target attribute, simply use the xml:id value contained in the note or bibl element that needs to be linked. You can also link to the general bibliography section with the target value "#bibliography" For example:
div.label: Links to Other Texts or Web Addresses:
div.p: If there is a link to a milestone in a different text, rather than using a ptr, the ref element is used which should also have a "target" attribute followed by the URL address of the text, followed by a hash tag followed by the xml:id of the milestone in that other text. For example.

div.head: Guidelines for Glossary
Some notes about how the glossary works:
div.label: How reader handles plurals:
div.p: A term will be matched if it is followed by s, es, 's or s' and then a non-word character e.g. Maitreya, Maitreya's, Maitreyas. (Unfortunately the general marker for non-word characters is not Sanskrit aware. It handles Sanskrit diacritic characters as non-word characters. While we have handled most of the related issues in this case it can result in a few mistakes. e.g. Maitreyasāyana).
div.label: Use of term tag to differentiate marking the same word used in different ways:
div.p: Some times we will only want certain instances of a string of text to be marked as a glossary term. For example, perhaps we want the term "appropriate" to be linked to this term when it is used as verb but not when it used as an adjective. Note, that we are no longer using zero-width-non-joiners to resolve this issue. Instead, we now use the "mode" attribute within the gloss element.

In the glossary gloss nodes can be given an attribute of mode="match|marked" Match mode will highlight any matches in the text except where they have been marked up with term type="ignore" e.g. parse this but not this . Marked mode will only match terms that have been marked up with term e.g. Ignore this but match this.
div.label: How Tibetan is created from Wylie:
div.p: Where a glossary item has a Wylie term but no Tibetan the database will auto-generate the Tibetan. To re-create a Tibetan term simply remove the node, save and refresh. The Wylie string will also have a trailing space enforced. These will produce the respective syllable separators in the Tibetan. Double underscores in Wylie will be replaced with a single space when output to the reader.
div.label: Links to paragraphs with instances:
div.p: The reader lists links to each paragraph that includes instances of a glossary term.
div.label: For multiple Tibetan and Sanskrit Forms of Spelling for a Single Term:
div.p: In some cases a single gloss entry may have multiple forms for spelling the Tibetan, the Sanskrit, or both. In this case each spelling of term can be listed separately in its own term element. However, Tibetan should be listed first followed by the Sanskrit as in the following example for the term "karnikara" (note that a Tibetan "bo" term is auto-generated after each instance of Tibetan Wylie "Bo-Ltn"):

gloss.term: Pterospermum acerifolium. Other names include bayur, muchakunda, muchalinda, and dinner-plate tree.

div.p: Note that in the example above, these spelling variations are supplied by the author but don't actually appear in the translated text. If there are alternative spellings of a term within the text itself, they need to be marked as type="alternative".
div.label: Use of Alternatives in the Glossary Entry:
div.p: Glossary items can also include term type="alternative" nodes to specify other variations in the spelling that should be marked in the text,
div.label: Further Explanation on the Mode Attribute:
div.p: The mode attribute is not required but when present it can either be "match" or "marked". "Match" is the default (where this attribute is not specified this will apply). "Match" will behave in the normal way: the text is scanned for glossary matches and highlighted accordingly.
"Marked" on the other hand will only consider text strings that have been marked up with term. An example for "appropriate" is below.

egXML.p: Bhadrapāla said, “Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying person’s limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, appropriate another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it appropriate different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying person’s sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body?”

div.head: Guidelines for Entering Milestones into the TEI Document
div.p: Milestones are applied to the document with the “milestone unit="chunk"/” tag. Because the 84,000 reading room does not have page numbers, milestones are particularly important for referencing sections or paragraphs in the text.

Milestones should be applied to the text at places where there is a logical/thematic division in the text. Often, milestones can be placed at the beginning of each paragraph of prose. In cases where paragraphs are very short (only one or two sentences) milestones can be placed one for every two or more paragraphs depending on the context, or a particularly short paragraph can share the milestone with that of a larger previous or later paragraph that shares the same “theme”.

To a large degree the editor should use their own judgment: If the milestones are too frequent, then it will become distracting to the reader on the page. If they are too far apart, it will be difficult to cite particular passages of the text. It is helpful to check the display in the reading room after applying milestones to make sure they appear in a convenient way.

Often there will be very short paragraphs used during sections of dialogue. A logical way to organize these sections is to allow one question and answer to be given a single milestone. For example, the following passage could be given one milestone:

egXML.p: The Lord then said to the venerable Śāriputra, “Śāriputra, did you see that universe Abhirati, and the Tathāgata Akṣobhya?”

Śāriputra replied, “I saw it, Lord! May all living beings come to live in a buddhafield as splendid as that! May all living beings come to have miraculous powers just like those of the noble Licchavi Vimalakīrti!

div.p: If either the question or the answer are very short paragraphs (one or two sentences), then they could be appended to the milestone along with their respective question and answer. However, if both the question and answer are long paragraphs in themselves, they should each be given their own milestone. Of course, there will always be unique situations such as questions being answered with another question and so forth. The editor should in general use their own discretion to decide what frequency of milestones would be the most useful and least distracting to the reader. They should to try to be consistent with their usage.

When entering milestones for lines of verse, the editor should apply milestones in a consistent manner, which will typically be one milestone marker between every line group element lg. Usually this will be a verse of four lines in English.
For example, see how milestones are applied to the following verses from The Teachings of Vimalakīrti:

lg.l: Pure are your eyes, broad and beautiful, like the petals of a blue lotus.
Pure is your thought, having discovered the supreme transcendence of all trances.
Immeasurable is the ocean of your virtues, the accumulation of your good deeds.
You affirm the path of peace. O Great Ascetic, obeisance to you!
Leader, bull of men, we behold the revelation of your miracle.
The superb and radiant fields of the sugatas appear before us,
And your extensive spiritual teachings, that lead to immortality
Make themselves heard throughout the whole reach of space.
Dharma-King, you rule with the Dharma your supreme Dharma-kingdom,
And thereby bestow the treasures of the Dharma upon all living beings.
Expert in the deep analysis of things, you teach their ultimate meaning.
Sovereign Lord of Dharma, obeisance to you!

div.p: Another rare case the editor may encounter is short sentences used in a debate like dialogue. For example, in this following dialogue found in The Teachings of Vimalakīrti:

egXML.p: Mañjuśrī: What is the great compassion of a bodhisattva ?
Vimalakīrti: It is the giving of all accumulated roots of virtue to all living beings.
Mañjuśrī: What is the great joy of the bodhisattva?
Vimalakīrti: It is to be joyful and without regret in giving.
Mañjuśrī: What is the equanimity of the bodhisattva?
Vimalakīrti: It is what benefits both self and others.
Mañjuśrī: To what should one resort when terrified by fear of life?
Vimalakīrti: Mañjuśrī, a bodhisattva who is terrified by fear of life should resort to the magnanimity of the Buddha.
“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of virtuous application. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who live by all virtuous principles will be born in his buddhafield.

“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is the magnificence of the conception of the spirit of enlightenment. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who are actually participating in the Mahāyāna will be born in his buddhafield.
“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of generosity. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who give away all their possessions will be born in his buddhafield.
“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of morality. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who follow the path of the ten virtues with positive thoughts will be born in his buddhafield.

div.p: Here the editor might place a milestone for each item in the list depending on the length of each paragraph. It might also be appropriate to place the milestones according to logical groupings in the list, for example place one milestone for the four immeasurables, one milestone for the six paramitas, etc. Finally, if the list becomes overburdened by milestones, the editor can add the milestones for every two or four items in the list. In this case it might be worthwhile to check how many items there are in the list then seek a reasonable way to divide it up evenly.

In general, it’s most important to think of milestone placement according to logical connections and divisions within the text itself. Try to group long paragraphs with shorter ones if the shorter paragraph is concluding the ideas of the longer paragraph; try to group items in a list that are related; try to group questions and answers together (where the question gets the milestone and the answer shares the same milestone without getting its own). If there are no logical groupings and many short paragraphs or items in a list, then try to apply consistently according to number (e.g. every two paragraphs, or every four, etc).
If the editor is not sure about the frequency for applying milestones, he or she can refer to some of the other texts in the reader and see how frequently the milestones are used in other texts.

div.head: Guidelines for entering Soft Hyphens to Sanskrit
div.p: Note that only editors with a basic understanding of spelling and sandhi rules of Sanskrit should proceed with this step. You don't need to be an expert in Sanskrit, as most words can be looked up in online references, however, for this step editors will need to have a clear grasp on how the sandhi rules in Sanskrit work. If not please request that another editor with this skill to complete this task.

list.item: Look for long Sanskrit chains, and add optional soft-hyphens at points where there are chains that are 15+ characters long. (Note: you should have some familiarity with Sanskrit to do this task, if not please ask another editor to do this part) Optional soft-hyphens are created with the character code: ­Note after you save the XML these will look like regular hyphens, but if you move the blinking cursor to the space just before the hyphen you will notice there is a different character code displayed at the bottom of the oXygen screen.

The long Sanskrit chains can be found easily by going to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder, then in the XPath/XQuery Builder window type the following code and press the red play button://*[string-length(string()) > 14 and @xml:lang ='Sa-Ltn'] You can save this query for later by clicking on the star and choosing "add to favourites."

Be careful when adding the soft hyphens as they should only be placed at certain points in the words where they do not interfere with the Sanskrit rules of sandhi. When adding the soft hyphens please follow the following guidelines:

item.label: Guidelines for adding Soft-Hyphens to Sanskrit

item.p: 1. As we are not using full justification anyway, (a) most Sanskrit words don’t need hyphenation unless they are longer than 5 or 6 syllables, but (b) may be necessary for shorter words especially in text titles on the title page. I therefore tend to place soft hyphens in all of the text titles, in verse passages, in the bibliography entries, and in notes and glossary entries (which require shorter lines in general).

2. Place a soft hyphen (a) only between the words of a compound; (b) even then only when there are no changes brought about by sandhi (because putting a hyphen would logically mean undoing the sandhi, and the hyphens we’re talking about may or may not appear; and (c) avoiding confusing remnants.

Ratnagotravibhāgottaratantraśāstra would be Ratna-gotra-vibhāgottara-tantra-śāstra. If we divided the 5-syllable sequence in the middle, that would have to undo the sandhi and become -vibhāga-uttara- which only works in the presence of a hard hyphen. Theoretically we could put a hyphen at vi-bhāga, but that would risk leaving us with -gotravi- , which would be potentially confusing to read.

The maximum we could hyphenate antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhisaṃdhisamuccedaka would be antānanta-ḍṛṣṭi-vāsanābhi-saṃdhi-sam-ucchedaka, because antānanta and vāsanābhi-saṃdhi would become anta-ananta and vāsana-abhi-saṃdhi. In a case like that, I would also prefer to avoid ending up with antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhi-saṃdhisamuccedaka, because the abhi- really belongs with the saṃdhi; it’s a possible break but is confusing to read.

list.item: One resource that is helpful for determining the breaks in Sanskrit chains in the online Cologne Sanskrit Dictionary. This one is really helpful because it has a drop down menu of similarly spelled words when you hit the enter key, however, I think this only works when you use the Kyoto-Harvard Transliteration scheme "KH". I don't know you might try the other ones but I found that this is the only one that gave the drop down list for me. Than when you find a big word in the dictionary in the definition entry you will see * whenever there is sandhi, though this isn't 100% reliable, sometimes it is missing for some reason, so be careful if the spelling looks weird.

In certain cases there may be long 15+ Sanskrit chains that cannot be broken due to the sandhi, or long Sanskrit compounds whose pieces cannot be easily determined with online resources. If this is the case make a list of problematic instances to note to the leading editors, also check these instances to see if the pose any major difficultly for the web display. These instances are rare, but they do come up now and then.
It is acceptable to add an optional hyphen at the end of "mahā-" as in "mahā-yāna" even though technically the long ā would be lost as this is a well known word and unlikely to be misread.

Note that when you add the optional hyphens to a glossary item where the translation uses the Sanskrit (This will mainly be in the “Persons” and “Places” section of the glossary) the hyphens will have to match all those instances within the body of the text or they will not link to the glossary term, so it is best to start from the glossary and work your way backwards. For all of these person and place terms do a search and replace so that the hyphens match in all the instances of that term (be cautious when doing large search-and-replaces that you don’t make any unintended changes)
